Experience


Data Scientist


Statistics Canada   2020 - present  Ottawa, Canada


Develop and maintain POHEM (a longitudinal microsimulation model that forecasts various health risk factors and outcomes — obesity, diabetes, dementia, cardiovascular disease — in Canadians from 2001 to 2050) that is used by the Government of Canada to inform policy decisions.


Authored and maintain chms (an internal, object-oriented R package that applies sleep, physical activity and sedentary behaviour algorithms to accelerometer-measured time series data) that a division with no open source expertise used to process accelerometer data on 4,000+ participants for cycle 7 of a nationally representative survey, the Canadian Health Measures Survey.


Authored and maintain ompp4aaw (an internal R package that allows users with little or no proficiency in Linux distributions and Kubernetes to install, compile and run their models) that is used by model developers across several microsimulation divisions.


Authored and maintain Data Dictionary Builder (an R Shiny web-based app that groups survey metadata from flat files across multiple cycles of several national surveys and makes it searchable) that enables Statistics Canada analysts and external researchers to find variables and plan analyses more efficiently.


Modeled Covid-19 cases in nine Canadian provinces on a weekly basis during the Covid-19 pandemic using compartment models via a co-authored R package, EpiSim. Created scenarios that forecasted Covid-19 cases one year into the future. Results were used downstream in a Microsoft Azure pipeline to help the Government of Canada forecast personal protective equipment demand and make evidence-informed procurement decisions.
